In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In October 2011, at the Partnership Assembly Meeting in Istanbul, several countries, 
including Viet Nam, submitted an expression of interest to participate in the Partnership for 
Market Readiness (PMR) program, a grant-based capacity building trust fund that provides 
funding  and  technical  assistance  for  collective  innovation  and  piloting  of  market-based 
instruments for greenhouse gas emissions reduction. To promote innovation and provide a 
platform for technical discussion, the PMR brings together developed and developing countries, 
as well as other key experts and stakeholders, in particular to foster South–South exchange on 
how to improve mitigation action. At the PMR 2011 meeting, Viet Nam requested that the 
Partnership Assembly approve the Asian Development Bank (ADB) as its main delivery partner 
and the World Bank as its co-delivery partner in carrying out PMR activities. 
 
2.  The technical assistance (TA) supports the Government of Viet Nam’s National Target 
Program for responding to climate change, the National Climate Change Strategy, as well as 
Viet Nam’s proposed strategy for green growth. A TA fact-finding mission visited Viet Nam and 
reached an agreement with the government on the TA impact, outcome, outputs, activities, cost, 
implementation and financing arrangements, and terms of reference. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.1  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  In Viet Nam, strong economic growth and industrialization after the financial crisis of 
1997 was largely fuelled by intense exploitation of natural resources. Viet Nam’s industrial 
growth has driven annual increases in energy consumption and corresponding greenhouse gas 
emissions. In 2008, growth in energy consumption was 11.3%, a consistent trend after the 1997 
crisis. Resource consumption comprises primarily oil and coal, and amounts to 28,479 kilotons 
of oil equivalent. If this trend continues as projected, with Viet Nam continuing its heavy reliance 
on fossil fuels, national greenhouse gas emissions (which were 177 tons of carbon dioxide 
equivalent in 2005) will triple by 2030. Moreover, Viet Nam’s per capita energy consumption is 
projected to reach 5,400 kilowatt-hours by 2030, up from 985 kilowatt-hours in 2010. Currently, 
52% of electricity consumption is from the industry and business sectors, 39% from residential 
areas,  and  8%  from  agriculture.  The  large  increase  in  energy  demand  and  requisite 
infrastructure investment required to satisfy energy needs in an environmentally sustainable 
manner poses a significant challenge, particularly given Viet Nam’s significant exposure to 
climate change impacts. Increased temperatures and reduced dry season rainfall will increase 
power demand for cooling and pumping. In the medium term, the government's plans to meet 
these growing needs include a mix of new coal and hydropower projects.  
 
4.  The magnitude of the challenge is daunting, and an estimated $40 billion will be required 
to meet the growing energy needs in Viet Nam while transitioning to a low-carbon path. Current 
plans estimate that, by 2015, energy demand will be met through coal, hydropower, and natural 
gas, increasingly supplemented by nuclear and renewable energy sources such as solar, wind, 
and small-scale hydropower. The government has committed to transition to market-oriented 
pricing that will reduce the demand for coal compared to cleaner-burning natural gas and other 
energy sources. Specific initiatives include the following:  
(i)  The Law on Environmental Protection Tax, which came into effect January 2012, 
aims at using an indirect tax for products and goods which, when used, have 
negative impacts on the environment.2  
                                                
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 4 January 2013.  
2  This law was adopted under Decision No. 57/2010/QH12.

2   
(ii)  The Green Growth Strategy approved in September 2012, has three focus areas: 
(a) reducing greenhouse gases, particularly to reduce greenhouse gas emissions 
for energy activities by 10% (20% with international support) for 2011–2020 and 
by  30%  (45%  with  international  support)  for  2020–2030  compared  with  the 
business-as-usual scenario, (b) greening production, and (c) green lifestyle.3   
(iii)  The Law on Energy Efficiency and Conservation, effective since January 2011, 
ensures energy security.4 
(iv)  Viet Nam’s action programs for energy efficiency and large-scale development of 
renewable energy sources, which have three medium- to long-term objectives: (a) 
to  reduce  energy  consumption  per  gross  domestic  product  by  at  least          
2.5%–3.0% per year by 2020; (b) to reduce total greenhouse gases relative to 
business-as-usual by 2%–3% per year from 2020 to 2030; and (c) to increase the 
share of renewable energies in the total power generation mix to 5.6% in 2020 
and  11.0%  in  2050,  of  which  20,000–22,000  megawatts  is  planned  from 
hydropower and 1,600 megawatts from biomass.  
 
5.  Changes in pricing are likely to provide some incentives for clean reliable energy. There 
is a need to mobilize financial resources from all possible channels, including carbon market 
mechanisms. In November 2010, the United Nations Secretary General's High Level Advisory 
Group  on  Climate  Change  Financing  presented  a  report  on  potential  financial  sources  to 
support  developing  countries  in  addressing  climate  change.  The  report  identified  carbon 
markets as one of the feasible ways to scale up long-term financing to plug the existing gap in 
international climate financing for developing countries to address climate change. 
 
6.  With this background, the Clean Development Mechanism approach has demonstrated 
the role market instruments can play in the carbon market by supporting the cost-effective 
reduction  of  greenhouse  gas  emissions  and  channeling  mitigation  finance  to  developing 
countries. It is widely recognized that it is necessary to increase the participation of developing 
countries in the carbon market. Expansion of the existing carbon market and introduction of new 
market-based mechanisms requires improved international awareness on the role of market-
based mechanisms, as well as increased national and international capacity for designing, 
implementing, and overseeing such mechanisms in developing countries. To effectively scale-
up international carbon markets, a well-designed and structured approach to capacity building 
needs to be adopted. To facilitate these efforts, the PMR program was launched at the 16th 
Conference of the Parties of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change in 
Cancun,  Mexico  in  2010.  The  PMR  is  intended  to  help  interested  countries  reach  these 
objectives, and it was decided at the outset that the World Bank would act as trustee of the 
PMR activities and administer the PMR Multi-Donor Trust Fund with an aim of $100 million in 
contributions from the various donor countries. The 16 countries that volunteered to participate 
in this initiative are Brazil, Chile, People’s Republic of China, Colombia, Costa Rica, India, 
Indonesia, Jordan, Mexico, Morocco, Peru,5 South Africa, Thailand, Turkey, Ukraine, and Viet 
Nam.  
 
7.  The  PMR  has  two  phases:  (i)  the  preparation  phase  for  preparing  the  organizing 
framework and the market readiness proposal (MRP), which details the country’s plan for its

promote energy efficiency and use natural resources with high added value. 
4  The law was adopted under Decision No. 50/2010/QH12. 
5  Initially the PMR was limited to 15 countries and Peru only joined in October 2012 with the understanding that its

3 
proposed  market-based  instrument(s)  and  market  readiness  components,  and  (ii)  the 
implementation phase for piloting the proposed market instrument(s) where possible. Viet Nam, 
along  with  four  other  countries,  submitted  an  organizing  framework  in  May  2012  for 
consideration  by  the  Partnership  Assembly,  which  approved  it  and  allocated  funding  of 
$315,000  at  its  third  meeting  held  in  Cologne,  Germany.  This  funding  will  support  the 
formulation of the MRP and complete the preparation phase. 
 
8.  Viet Nam intends to initially apply market-based instruments to selected sectors with a 
view to broadening the scope over time and achieve broad-based carbon pricing. Under the TA, 
this approach to developing market-based instruments in Viet Nam will be supported by 
(i)  studying and deploying potential market-based instruments in steel, solid waste 
management, and power (energy efficiency) industries; 
(ii)  integrating market-based instruments in the development of planning and policy 
and coordination to assess their use in mainstreaming green growth; 
(iii)  further developing a draft proposal on greenhouse gas emissions management 
using market-based mechanisms and establishing and managing a monitoring, 
reporting, and verification (MRV) system; and 
(iv)  preparing emission profiles, preparing business-as-usual scenarios (for cities), 
and identifying emission reduction options including approval and implementation 
of nationally appropriate mitigation actions and market-based instruments and 
MRV systems for sectors and regions. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The expected TA impact will be piloting of market-based instruments for greenhouse gas 
emissions reduction in Viet Nam. The outcome will be the MRP is endorsed by the Government 
of Viet Nam for presentation to the Partnership Assembly in the first half of 2014. The TA will 
assist  the  country  in  preparing  the  MRP  and,  if  successful,  will  prepare  the  project  for 
implementation. The key highlights of the proposal are Viet Nam’s national plan for its proposed 
crediting mechanisms, market-based instrument(s), and market readiness components, and the 
financing needs for the implementation phase. 
 
10.  The TA will also contribute to fulfilling the goals set by the National Target Program in 
addressing climate change issues within  the context of poverty alleviation and sustainable 
development. By developing its market readiness and using market mechanisms (in particular, a 
new scaled-up greenhouse gas crediting mechanism), Viet Nam will be better positioned to 
support its strategy on green growth and introduce clean technologies.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  To prepare the MRP in line with the guidelines set forth by the Partnership Assembly, 
under the TA (i) a participatory and consultative approach will be adopted in project planning, 
design,  and  implementation  to  ensure  strong  ownership;  (ii)  where  necessary,  formal 
agreements will be adopted to define key responsibilities; and (iii) existing networks will be 
tapped to identify and engage qualified experts for the project. ADB will be the main delivery 
partner for the government, with the World Bank as co-delivery partner in implementing the 
activities under this TA.

4   
12.  The MRP will be developed on a sector-specific basis and will build on the country’s 
existing initiatives to meet nationally defined priorities. The methodology for developing the MRP 
will include (i) carrying out a feasibility and capacity assessment for utilizing market mechanisms 
in the context of the country’s mitigation strategies; (ii) improving data collection systems and 
institutional capacity for data reporting and management and for setting up activity reference 
levels;  and  (iii)  designing  or  enhancing  existing  MRV  frameworks  to  ensure  transparency, 
quality, credibility, and consistency with international good practice. 
 
13.  A  team  of consultants will  support  the government focal  points  responsible  for  the 
PMR―the  Ministry  of  Natural  Resources  and  Environment  (MONRE)  and  the  Ministry  of 
Planning and Investment (MPI). The preparation of a comprehensive MRP for Viet Nam will 
focus specifically on (i) central coordination, organization, communication, consultation, and 
engagement; (ii)  overview  of  the  country  policy  context  and  mitigation  objective;  (iii)  MRV 
elements;  (iv)  the  regulatory  and  institutional  framework;  and  (v)  scaled-up  crediting 
mechanisms, emission trading system principles, and design of pilot activities (e.g., energy 
efficiency measures in selected cities). At the Partnership Assembly meeting in May 2012, the 
government’s  organizing  framework  proposed  three  pilot  crediting  mechanisms:  (i)  energy 
efficiency in the power industry, (ii) industrial energy efficiency in the steel industry, and (iii) solid 
waste management.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $346,500 of which, $315,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Partnership for Market Readiness Multi-Donor Trust Fund6 and administered by 
ADB. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are provided in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  MPI will be the executing agency, although implementation will be co-led by the MPI and 
MONRE in the preparation phase in cooperation with the Ministry of Industry and Trade, which 
oversees  the  power  and  steel  industries  in  Viet  Nam.  Interministerial  coordination  and 
consistency of the government’s sector strategies and related policies will be managed and 
monitored through frequent interministerial dialogues. The TA implementation period is from 
June 2013 to June 2014.   
 
16.  The overall MRP preparation is envisaged to consist of two distinct activities executed by 
a firm engaged using the fixed-budget selection method with a lump-sum contract. This method 
is preferred as the budget is fixed and cannot be exceeded, and it minimizes the risk for ADB. In 
its proposal, the consultant will prepare a budget to carry out the required tasks. The activity-
based budget will be linked to clear outputs and services. Payments will be made in installments 
based on the delivery of the contractually agreed deliverables. It is estimated that 10 person-
months  of  international  consultant  services  and  10  person-months  of  national  consultant 
services  will  be  required.  Consultant  engagement  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) and disbursements 
under  the  TA  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook  (2010,  as  amended from  time to time). The  detailed  terms  of  reference  are  in 
Appendix 3.  
 
17.  The consultants will support the MPI and MONRE in the preparation of a comprehensive 
proposal for Viet Nam, focusing on (i) project coordination, (ii) mitigation options for priority

5 
sectors to be determined during the TA, (iii) market-based instruments, and (iv) design of pilot 
activities (e.g., energy efficiency measures in the steel industry). Where mitigation options are 
deemed suitable for elaboration into nationally appropriate mitigation action(s) that may be 
scaled-up for crediting and/or trading mechanisms, the team will convene consultations with 
stakeholders and experts in the designated sectors.  
 
18.  The project will be country-led and build on nationally defined and prioritized mitigation 
policies according to its national circumstances. The TA will also coordinate with a number of 
countries  that  have  initiated  comprehensive  country-specific  studies  to  assess  their 
development goals and priorities, in conjunction with mitigation opportunities. By doing this, the 
PMR will synergize with other readiness efforts to avoid duplication and ensure effective use of 
resources. The PMR should complement and coordinate with the relevant initiatives at both the 
international and national levels. To ensure comprehensive and consistent approaches, the 
PMR will collaborate with other agencies as needed through workshops and donor coordination 
meetings under the guidance of the MPI and MONRE.  
 
19.  Consultant mobilization is expected for the second quarter of 2013. During preparation of 
the MRP, ADB and the World Bank will organize meetings under the auspices of the MPI and 
MONRE to gather feedback. ADB and World Bank staff assigned in Viet Nam will oversee 
consultants’ work and provide monitoring and technical support. The draft final MRP endorsed 
by the government will be submitted to the PMR Secretariat for the expert group feedback 
process.7 This  process  allows  the  participating  country  to  revise  the  draft  MRP  with  the 
feedback received and to address outstanding issues prior to its formal submission for securing 
implementation funding from the Partnership Assembly. The government’s presentation of the 
draft MRP to the Partnership Assembly is targeted for no later than May 2014.8  
 
IV.  THE RANKING VICE-PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
20.  The  Ranking  Vice-President,  acting  in  the  absence  of  the  President,  under  the 
provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, and acting under the authority 
delegated by the Board, has approved ADB administering technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $315,000 to the Government of Viet Nam to be financed on a grant basis by 
the  Partnership  for  Market  Readiness  Multi-Donor  Trust  Fund  for  Developing  the  Market 
Readiness Proposal for a Domestic Carbon Market, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                
7  The  expert  group  feedback is  a  process designed  to  give  implementing  country  participants  an additional 
perspective on their proposed activities for PMR support and, ultimately, to strengthen their overall proposals. In 
addition to electronic communication between the experts and the implementing country participant, the PMR 
Secretariat will finance one member of an expert group to conduct an in-country meeting as part of the overall 
feedback process. The implementing country participant will also mobilize its own resources to offset the cost of 
expert visits, particularly if it wishes to have more than one expert visit during the feedback process. 
8  As a standard rule, all implementing country participants are required to present their final MRP no later than 2 
years after approval of the expression of interest. In Viet Nam’s case, this implies a deadline of May 2014 as the 
expression of interest was submitted in May 2012.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.  Activity 1: Central Coordination, Communication, Consultation, and Management 
 
1.  Objective 
 
1.  A team of consultants will be recruited through a firm to support the Ministry of Planning 
and  Investment  (MPI)  and  Ministry  of  Natural  Resources  and  Environment  (MONRE)  in 
preparing a comprehensive market readiness proposal (MRP) for Viet Nam, building on the 
PMR organizing framework submitted by the Government of Viet Nam in May 2012 at the 
Partnership Assembly meeting in Cologne, Germany. The consultants will focus on the central 
coordination, communication, consultation, and management activities for the preparation of 
Viet  Nam’s  proposal  and  will  prepare  a  draft  MRP,  and  subsequently  a  final  MRP.1 It  is 
estimated that 10 person-months of international consultant services and 10 person-months of 
national consultant services will be required to deliver the outputs. 
 
2.  Scope of Work 
 
2.  The consultants’ scope of work will include the tasks outlined in the paras below.  
 
3.  Coordinate activities related to greenhouse gas management in Viet Nam. The firm 
will assign one consultant as the project coordinator who will support MONRE and MPI in 
coordinating and implementing activities related to greenhouse gas management in Viet Nam. 
The coordinator will concurrently be responsible for reviewing, coordinating, and supervising 
implementation of the studies prepared in support of the MRP by various consultants. The 
coordinator will review the progress of the tasks in this program, organize and arrange meetings 
and workshops as required, and ensure that all tasks are completed as per requirements, timing, 
and overall agreed approach.  
 
4.  This task includes communication and consultation in support of preparation of the MRP 
among line ministries, development partners, and civil society. To report project progress and 
review approaches, the coordinator will regularly consult with and receive feedback from the 
joint Asian Development Bank–World Bank task team and the Government of Viet Nam’s PMR 
focal points. The coordinator will also support the government in preparing the PMR feedback 
process and coordinate queries, comments, and suggestions that may be communicated by the 
PMR expert group and participants.  
 
5.  Develop the country policy context analysis. The firm will provide a comprehensive 
analysis of the country’s broader development and climate change mitigation objectives. The 
assessment will follow the outline of the Tool for MRP building block 1 and build on existing data 
and studies to avoid duplication (footnote 1). 
 
6.  Compile  studies  and  draft  final  document. The project coordinator, following the 
guidance provided by the PMR Secretariat’s Tool for MRP, will consolidate all inputs (from new 
and existing studies and from consultation processes) and (i) ensure that the documents are 
adequately written in English, (ii) aggregate and normalize the information, and (iii) present the 
information in one coherent document. The result will be a proposal of the final MRP to be

reviewed  and  approved  by  the  PMR  focal  point,  in  coordination  with  the  PMR  steering 
committee and Partnership Assembly.  
 
7.  Prepare a capacity building plan for the government. The project coordinator will 
propose a plan for (i) organizing and coordinating PMR activities within the government and 
other  planned  low-carbon,  green  growth,  and  carbon  market  activities  within  the  country’s 
government;  (ii)  identifying  training  needs  and  capacity  building  requirements;  and  (iii) 
identifying communication and cooperation needs, and initiating an engagement process among 
government agencies, development partners, and stakeholders. 
 
3.  Deliverables 
 
8.  Specifically, the consultants will perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Along  with  the  government’s  PMR  task  group,  (a)  review,  coordinate,  and 
supervise notes and documents for the studies to be developed; (b) provide 
guidance and coordinate the work of the other consultants and the progress of 
the  studies  in  this  program;  and  (c)  ensure  the  set  up  and  coordination  of 
meetings, consultation, and communication and ensure that the contents of each 
research project fulfills the requirements, timing, and agreed approach for the 
final project. 
(ii)  Produce a reviewed compilation of the studies prepared by other consultants, 
and an annotated outline for the MRP in coordination with the PMR task team. 
(iii)  Produce an assessment of the country policy context with a specific focus on the 
areas to be financed under the MRP. 
(iv)  Produce  an  assessment  of  the  ongoing related  assistance  in-country  with  a 
specific focus on the areas to be financed under the MRP. 
(v)  Produce a draft of the MRP and assist the government in preparing the final draft 
to be presented to the Partnership Assembly.  
(vi)  Organize a consultation meeting(s) on the working draft of the MRP, with the 
participation of the various stakeholders, the delivery partners, and the PMR 
Secretariat, which should be held before initiating the PMR  expert feedback 
process. 
(vii)  Develop  a  comprehensive  and  detailed  budget  for  the  PMR  implementation 
phase which clearly defines the capacity building and infrastructure needs, the 
activities,  and  the  subsequent  funding  requirements  for  implementation  (the 
outputs  and  budget  subitems  should  be  clearly  identified,  presented,  and 
monitored with an associated timetable). 
 
9.  The  products  delivered  under  the  contract  by  the  consultants  must  be  mutually 
satisfactory to the focal points (i.e., the MPI and MONRE) as well as the delivery partners (i.e., 
ADB  and  the  World  Bank).  Participation  of  the  MPI  and  MONRE  will  be  sought  if  any 
substantive and technical information is shared between the consultants and ADB and the 
World Bank. Where this is not possible, the MPI and MONRE will be informed in a timely 
manner on the substance of any such discussions. The focal points and delivery partners will be 
entitled to use and share the project results within the project framework. Any information 
transferred to a third party will require prior consent. Deliverables must be prepared in English 
and completed within the date agreed upon mobilization. If required, a Vietnamese translation 
should also be prepared if requested by the Government of Viet Nam within the firm’s consulting 
contract.

Appendix 3  11 
B.  Activity  2:  Preparation  of  Potential  Market-Based  Instruments  for  Steel,  Solid 
Waste Management, and Power (Energy Efficiency) Industries 
 
1.  Consultants’ Outputs 
 
10.  In line with the Tool for Market Readiness Proposal, the selected firm will support the 
government  in  preparing  potential  market-based  instruments  in  the  steel,  solid  waste 
management, and power (energy efficiency) industries. In broad terms, the firm is expected to 
support the government in formulating an MRP through preparation of the components listed in 
paras 11–16.2 
 
11.  Market  readiness  assessment  of  the  identified  industries  (10%).  The  firm  will 
provide a comprehensive analysis of the steel, solid-waste management, and power (energy 
efficiency) industries, as well as of existing energy efficiency programs. It will also determine the 
rationale for its selection, which will serve as the basis for assessing the suitability of using 
market-based instruments to successfully scale up mitigation efforts at the sector level.  
 
12.  Technical and institutional and/or regulatory market readiness components of the 
industries (10%). The firm will provide the information for each industry for the assessment and 
development of Viet Nam's core market readiness infrastructure and capacity, which will follow 
the outline of the Tool for MRP building block 3 (footnote 1).  
 
13.  Assessment  of  the  appropriate  market-based  instruments  (35%).  The  firm  will 
assess scaled-up greenhouse gas crediting instruments for the three industries,  and other 
options if available.  
 
14.  Preliminary design of a scaled-up greenhouse gas crediting instrument for the 
three industries (30%). A crediting instrument refers to a mechanism that credits reductions of 
greenhouse gas  emissions  against  a  pre-established  threshold (referred  to  as  a  "crediting 
baseline") which can then be used to compensate for, or to offset, emissions made elsewhere. 
Following the guidance in the Tool for MRP building block 4, the firm is expected to prepare a 
preliminary conceptual design of the scaled-up greenhouse gas crediting instrument. 
 
15.  Organization, communication, consultation, and engagement (10%). The firm will 
provide the information across the three industries following the outline of the Tool for MRP 
Building Block 5 (footnote1). 
 
16.  Market  readiness  proposal  implementation  plan  (5%).  The  firm  will  provide 
information across the three industries following the outline of the Tool for MRP building block 6 
(footnote1). 
 
2.  Deliverables 
 
17.  All deliverables must be prepared in English and completed within the date agreed upon 
at mobilization. Upon request of the Government of Viet Nam, a Vietnamese translation should 
be prepared within the firm’s consulting contract. 
 
18.  Market readiness assessment and rationale. By focusing on the steel, solid waste 
management, and power (energy efficiency) industries, the firm will assess the technical and 
                                                
2  Percentages are assigned to each task to guide the level of effort applied over the course of the consultants’ work.

12  Appendix 3 
institutional and/or /regulatory issues and arrangements and propose the appropriate market-
based instruments for each industry as per the descriptions agreed. 
 
19.  Preliminary  design  of  a  scaled-up  greenhouse  gas  crediting  instrument.  The 
design of a scaled-up greenhouse gas crediting instrument shall be presented as per agreement. 
 
C.  Consultant Qualifications and Selection 
 
20.  The consulting services for activities 1 and 2 will be performed by a qualified firm with 
significant experience in sustainable development and carbon finance, preferably in the region. 
The firm must also have  
(i)  proven experience in developing climate change mitigation options appropriate to 
the region; 
(ii)  in-depth knowledge of scaled-up crediting instruments; 
(iii)  understanding of implementation challenges in developing nationally appropriate 
monitoring, reporting, and verification systems; 
(iv)  strong capability to analyze policies, regulatory frameworks, and barriers related 
to sector sustainable development approaches; 
(v)  excellent  capacity  to  communicate  and  implement  sector  and  plenary 
consultations with key decision makers such as ministries; national and local 
government  agencies;  and  key  stakeholders  including  private  sector 
organizations,  nongovernment  organizations,  and  academia  relevant  to  the 
above-mentioned industries; 
(vi)  good knowledge of the local political economy; and 
(vii)  appropriate  capabilities  to  provide  technical  and  logistical  support  in  the 
formulation and preparation of Viet Nam’s market readiness proposal. 
 
21.  The contract will be executed by the selected firm, using the fixed-budget selection 
method with a lump-sum contract. The budget is fixed and cannot be exceeded. In its proposal, 
the firm will prepare a budget to implement the activities described. The activity-based budget 
will be linked to clear products, outputs, and services. Payments will be made in installments 
based  on  the  delivery  of  the  contractually  agreed  deliverables  and  outputs.  Consultant 
engagement will be done in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, 
as amended from time to time) and disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
ADB, the MPI, the MONRE, and the World Bank will supervise the consultants.  
 
22.  The  consultancy  requires  a first  draft  (presentation)  of  the  MRP  to  be finalized  by 
December 2013, and the final draft presentation document finalized by April 2014.
